Additionally, residents also accepted a proposition to purchase five (5) additional school buses by a vote of 1,862 (yes) to 1,399 (no).

Last but certainly not least, residents also elected Elaine Berlin, John Chandler and Kelly Firmbach to the Board of Education. Each seat on the board is for a 3-year term.

We thank all the residents who participated in this year’s budget vote and board election by returning their absentee ballots.

PS: Many thanks to our incredible ballot counters who stayed up late last night to ensure accurate results. A special HUGE shout out to our Board Clerk – Ms. Potts – for all her hard work during a very unconventional budget season.

Kailee is a student-athlete on the Ichabod Crane Riders Athletics Soccer Team (JV and Varsity) and was a captain her senior year. She is also involved in several clubs including: Spanish Club, Interact Club, Students Against Destructive Decisions (SADD), Girls Athletic Council (GAC), and National Honor Society.

She’s been recognized as the Salutatorian for the Class of 2020. She has won the High Point Junior Scholars Award, as well as the Gellert Cornell Admissions Invitation Award. She has also been a Rider of the Month.

She is extremely grateful for all of the staff who have helped her throughout the years. She would like to especially thank Mrs. Grizzaffi, Mrs. Knight, Mr. Sanger, and Mrs. DeAloe for supporting her and helping her achieve her goals.

After high school, Kailee plans to attend Bentley University to study Actuarial Science.

Senior Spotlight | Mark Liam Sappington

An Honor Roll Student-Athlete, Mark Liam has been on the Ichabod Crane Riders Athletics Riders Track and Field Team for all 4 years of high school. He’s been honored with Ceramics and Digital Arts awards (9th-12th grade) 3rd place in the Envirothon-Hudson Valley Regional and the Mastery designation on the New York State Earth Science Regents Exam (9th grade).

Through all of this, he’s also completed 80 hours in the Master 100 Ton American Marine Training Centers course for his Passenger Vessel Operators License.

He thanks and shouts out Mr. Sanger, Mr. Allard, Ms. Dwileski and Ms. Drummond.

After graduation, Mark Liam will spend the summer working in Alaska as an ocean sport fishing guide and in Fall 2020 he will begin boot camp for the US Marine Corps Reserves. Beyond that, he’s been accepted into Oregon State University where he will begin studying in Fall 2021. There he will focus on Fisheries and Wildlife with the intention of becoming a park service ranger.

Did you know we have a pretty amazing library system in Columbia County? Our new District Superintendent, Jason D. Thomson, found that out as he continued his journey meeting the community.

Being new to the area, Mr. Thomson needed a library card, so he visited Kinderhook Memorial Library where he met Library Director, AnnaLee Dragon. He found out not only does his library card do the obvious (borrowing books, movies etc.) but also gives access to their Museum Pass Program that lets you visit tons museum near and far for FREE!

Some participating museums include the MASS MoCA, the MiSci - Museum of Innovation & Science, Schenectady, The Hyde Collection and the National Museum of Dance.

We love having community partners like Kinderhook Memorial Library and encourage our district families to visit & sign-up for their own card if they’ve never taken advantage of the Columbia County Libraries.* Find everything you need in their newsletter at http://kinderhooklibrary.org/

*A KML card gives you access to ALL the Columbia County Libraries!

Competitive applicants fall in the upper quarter of the University at Albany’s entering class (93%+ high school grade point average / SAT Evidence-Based Reading and Writing: 630+; SAT Math: 630+).”

Two of our High School Juniors - Sophia Dunn and Emma Stigi - have artwork exhibited as part of the annual Art in Three Dimensions show at the Mohonasen CSD High School District Art Gallery from February 3-27. Congratulations to both these student artists, stop by to see their pieces and the rest of the show if you're in the area!

Emma's elegant ceramic pitcher with a floral design and Sophia's hand-cut paper relief sculpture based on the landscape of Zacapa, Guatemala are among the 82 works currently on display. Jurors Dawn Dishaw, a ceramic artist who lives and works in Mechanicville, NY, and Abe Ferraro, a sculptor, installation, and performance artist, who is currently the shop supervisor at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute School of Humanities, Arts, and Sciences juried the show out of a total of 200 submissions from schools all over the Capital Region.

Mrs. Kuhn's Family and Consumer Sciences (FACS) classes had a couple of special visitors from professionals in the healthcare industry.

-Justin Taylor, Sr - a certified EMT - spoke about how being a firefighter led him to his current position. He told the students how they can volunteer as "Junior Members" once they're 14. Volunteering, in turn, prepares you for your certification exam by getting hands-on experience. Mr. Taylor demonstrated emergency medical technologies for the students and explained the difference between EMTs and Paramedics.

-Cassandra Wellhausen - a registered nurse - spoke about her career at the Albany Med Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU). She also explored the options young people have for training and nursing certification that won't put them deeply in debt.

Thank you to both of them for taking the time to show our students some of the many rewarding career options in their field!

We're pleased to share that Ichabod Crane High School Senior, Trevor Wolfe, was recently honored for winning the Daughters of the American Revolution National Headquarters (DAR) Good Citizen's Scholarship Contest Program, sponsored in Columbia County by the Hendrick Hudson Chapter, NSDAR.

The program honors a single outstanding senior class member who demonstrates qualities of a good citizen and gives the student an opportunity to participate in the scholarship program at state and national levels. Competing students are nominated by their home school district and write an essay centered on how they try to manifest the qualities of a good citizen. This year's essay question was: "You are the nation's leader of tomorrow. How would you energize America's youth to fully engage as effective citizens and why is that important?"

Trevor was honored for his essay and achievement on December 15 at the DAR Hendrick Hudson Chapter House in Hudson, NY. Since Trevor was the selected candidate for the regional area, he now moves to the state level competition. Wish him luck!

If you didn't already know, December 5 (today) is Martin Van Buren's birthday. The eighth President of the United States, Van Buren was born in Kinderhook and returned here near the end of his life as well. The town holds an annual recognition ceremony at his gravesite in the Kinderhook Cemetary. It's a tradition to start the ceremony with a short presentation by Ichabod Crane students about Van Buren's life and accomplishments. As always they did a respectful and great job, even in the cold weather!

Congratulations to our seven high school students selected to attend the NYSSMA Area All-State Festival on November 22-23 at Hudson High School.

Students representing ICC at the Festival were: Victoria Slade (choir), Bridget Duso (choir), Miah Nooney (choir), Olivia Oligny-Leggett (choir), Anna O’Shea (choir), Alex Regan (concert band) and Meredith Buono (concert band).

To be in the Festival, each student was required to prepare and perform a solo for a New York State Schools Music Association (NYSSMA) adjudicator and sight-read a short melody. The highest-scoring students in Dutchess, Putnam & Columbia Counties were then selected to participate in the Festival this past weekend. Students rehearsed throughout Friday afternoon and Saturday morning, culminating in a Saturday afternoon concert under the direction of conductors from around New York State and beyond.
